getObjects
The function allows accessing the attributes of objects removed to the
Recycle bin
.
Syntax
def rb := recycleBin(typeObj,[attr]).getObjects()
Setting
Purpose
typeObj
Object type, the instances of which were added to the Recycle bin.
When working with a
primitive object with a surrogate key
, the type of the object to be retrieved must be specified, not the parent type.
attr
Type attribute(s) whose data need to be used in the current algorithm when retrieving the object.
This parameter is optional.
If the parameter is not specified, the object is formed only with the "Name" attribute.
Note
The function is called from the
Recycle bin
tab on the algorithm editor toolbar.
When the function is called, a modal window will open for selecting an object type, the instances of which were added to the
Recycle bin
.
The ability to view objects deleted by other users is available when the "Run" permission is granted for
"Viewing and restoring others' data from the Recycle bin"
.
After selecting an object type, the user can optionally specify its attribute(s) to be accessed within the algorithm, then click the "Done" button. This will insert the following code into the algorithm:
def rb := recycleBin(typeObj,[attr])
def rb_obj := rb.getObjects()
for (def object : rb_obj) {
if (object.attr == "Attribute Value") {
def id := object.ID
delete(id, true)  // delete object from the Recycle Bin
}
}
Example
For example, the "Request" object type stores information about customer requests. If a request is processed, it is marked with the "Closed" status.
Outdated requests that were placed in the Recycle bin and have the "Closed" status should be permanently deleted from the system, with no possibility of recovery.
To solve this task, the following algorithm can be used:
When calling the
getObjects
function, the "Request object type" is selected with the "Status" type attribute . As a result, the algorithm code will include a condition where the "Closed" status must be specified.
More about the functions used in the algorithm.
Within the algorithm, the
recycleBin
function is used to access the Recycle bin, and the
getObjects
function retrieves the deleted "Request" object.
Next, a loop is organized over the retrieved objects using the
for
operator, where the
if
operator checks the request status.
The "Closed" request status is added using the
dict
function.
Objects that meet the condition are added to the id
variable
, and then deleted from the Recycle bin using the
delete
function.
